confounder_hypotheses.reasoning: Pneumonia is a common lung infection that can cause both abnormal X-ray results (e.g., infiltrates) and dyspnea due to impaired gas exchange. It is highly prevalent and a strong confounder.
confounder_hypotheses.causal_graph: Pneumonia -> X-ray Result; Pneumonia -> Dyspnea Symptom

confounder_hypotheses.reasoning: COPD is a chronic condition that can lead to hyperinflation or other abnormalities on X-ray and is a major cause of dyspnea. It is common in smokers and older adults.
confounder_hypotheses.causal_graph: COPD -> X-ray Result; COPD -> Dyspnea Symptom

confounder_hypotheses.reasoning: Lung tumors can be visible on X-rays and cause dyspnea due to airway obstruction or pleural effusion. Though less common, it is a critical confounder.
confounder_hypotheses.causal_graph: Lung Cancer -> X-ray Result; Lung Cancer -> Dyspnea Symptom

confounder_hypotheses.reasoning: Heart failure can cause pulmonary edema, leading to abnormal X-ray findings (e.g., pleural effusion) and dyspnea due to fluid overload. It is a common comorbidity.
confounder_hypotheses.causal_graph: Congestive Heart Failure -> X-ray Result; Congestive Heart Failure -> Dyspnea Symptom
